articles.title: Why human-shaped robots loom large in Musk's Tesla plans
articles.summary: The tech billionaire believes Optimus could play a big role in the lives of people around the world.
articles.content:
Why human-shaped robots loom large in Musk's Tesla plans

19 hours ago Share Save Zoe Kleinman, Technology editor and Liv McMahon, Technology reporter Share Save

Getty Images

It has appeared in Tesla showrooms, on its factory floors and has even posed with Kim Kardashian. But Elon Musk's vision for his human-like robot Optimus is much grander than that. Since first unveiling it at a Tesla showcase in 2022, the tech billionaire has suggested his company's droid could play a huge role in the homes and lives of people all over the world. Along with self-driving robotaxis and Cybertrucks, Musk believes Tesla robots are key to establishing a foothold in the artificial intelligence (AI) landscape. And investors who signed off on his $1tn (£760bn) pay package on Thursday would appear to agree. One of the many tasks Musk must complete to get his whopping pay deal is to deliver a million AI bots over the next decade. But is Tesla's big bet on humanoid robots rooted in science fiction or reality?

Big potential

Silicon Valley is gunning hard for humanoids. A report released by Morgan Stanley on Friday predicted Apple, which is reportedly looking into the robots, could potentially earn $133bn a year from them by 2040. Foxconn is reported to be deploying them at its Nvidia factory in Texas. The idea of advanced AI within a human-shaped shell is an astonishingly powerful combination in theory. It would let the tech interact with the physical world around it – and yes that includes us. While many companies have sought to develop human-like robots for factory and industrial use - such as UK robotics firm Humanoid - some are already looking to insert the tech in homes. The highly-publicised Neo from tech firm 1X, slated to launch in 2026, can do menial chores like emptying the dishwasher, folding clothes and fetching you items. It will cost $20,000 but it does come with a caveat - the WSJ reported it was actually controlled by a person wearing a virtual reality headset. Forrester analyst Brian Hopkins said the falling costs of components, combined with improvements to robot dexterity and AI, was helping to make humanoid robots feasible for a variety of different settings. "From warehouses and restaurants to elder care and security, new use cases are gaining traction fast," he wrote in a blog post. "If current trajectories hold, humanoid robots could disrupt many physical-service industries significantly by 2030." Musk previously told investors his robots had "the potential to be more significant than the vehicle business, over time". He went one step further after his pay package deal was approved on Thursday, saying he believed it could be "the biggest product of all time by far, bigger than cell phones, bigger than anything". He has also suggested it might boost Tesla's AI ambitions - particularly in advancing artificial general intelligence (AGI) systems capable of matching human abilities. "Tesla AI might play a role in AGI, given that it trains against the outside world, especially with the advent of Optimus," he wrote on X in 2022. Elsewhere in the space, Boston Dynamics' hydraulic humanoid Atlas has captivated millions on YouTube with its gymnastics and dance routines. Viral videos of its leaps, bounds, somersaults and backflips have shown the advances in robotics over the years - with scientists now seizing upon the AI boom to boost their capabilities with systems enabling them to undertake more complex tasks. When it was retired last year, it was replaced with a newer, fully electric model developers said could contort its metal frame in even more ways.

articles.personality_title: Tesla’s Optimus robot aims to bring humanoid helpers to everyday life
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Elon Musk, the CEO of Tesla, introduced a human-shaped robot called Optimus in 2022. Tesla is known for electric cars, but Musk sees robots as an important future step, alongside self-driving cars and other AI projects.

**What happened** – Tesla plans to produce one million Optimus robots in the next ten years. These robots are designed to help with tasks around homes and workplaces. Other companies, like Apple and Foxconn, are also working on similar robots. Some robots already perform chores like folding clothes or emptying dishwashers, although earlier models sometimes need a human to control them.

**Impact** – Humanoid robots could change many parts of daily life and work, such as helping in factories, restaurants, and elder care. Experts believe these robots will become more affordable and skilled over the next decade. Elon Musk thinks Optimus could become Tesla’s most important product, even bigger than their cars or cell phones. This shows how serious Tesla is about using robots to improve how people live and work.

**What’s next step** – Tesla will focus on building and improving Optimus robots to make them useful for many tasks. As technology advances, we can expect smarter and more capable robots to appear in homes and workplaces. Other companies will likely continue developing similar robots, increasing competition and innovation in this field.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Tesla’s Optimus robot is a bold effort to bring helpful humanoid robots into everyday life, aiming to change how people live and work in the future.

articles.title: After 250 years, an 18th-century mechanical volcano erupts to life
articles.summary: An 18th-century mechanical artwork depicting Mount Vesuvius’ eruption has finally erupted — 250 years later. University of Melbourne students reconstructed Sir William Hamilton’s imaginative fusion of art and engineering using modern technology. Their re-creation glows with programmable lights and movement, reanimating history’s forgotten passion for science and spectacle.
articles.content:
An intricate mechanical model created in 1775 to capture the explosive beauty of Italy's Mount Vesuvius has erupted to life for the very first time, 250 years after it was first imagined. The recreation was made possible through modern engineering and the creative problem-solving of two University of Melbourne students.

The idea originated with Sir William Hamilton, the British ambassador to Naples and Sicily from 1765 to 1800, who was deeply fascinated by volcanoes. Blending art with early mechanical ingenuity, Hamilton designed a device that could visually simulate volcanic activity, bringing science and spectacle together in a single creation.

Inspired by the 1771 watercolor Night view of a current of lava by British-Italian artist Pietro Fabris, Hamilton's concept relied on light and motion to replicate glowing lava and eruptive bursts. Although no record confirms that it was ever built in his time, a detailed sketch preserved in the Bordeaux Municipal Library provided enough guidance for a modern reconstruction.

Reviving a Forgotten Experiment

Dr. Richard Gillespie, Senior Curator in the Faculty of Engineering and Information Technology, proposed reviving Hamilton's long-dormant idea and oversaw the project's completion.

"It is fitting that after 250 years exactly, our students have brought this dormant project to life," he said. "It is a wonderful piece of science communication. People around the world have always been fascinated by the immense power of volcanoes."

Modern Engineering Meets 18th-Century Imagination

Master of Mechatronics student Xinyu (Jasmine) Xu and Master of Mechanical Engineering student Yuji (Andy) Zeng spent three months constructing the device in The Creator Space student workshop. Using today's tools -- including laser-cut timber and acrylic, programmable LED lighting, and electronic control systems -- they reinterpreted Hamilton's clockwork concept for a new generation.

"The project offered a wealth of learning opportunities. I've extended many skills, including programming, soldering and physics applications," Ms. Xu said.

Mr. Zeng noted that the process helped him see mechanical design in a new light. "It was a fantastic way to build my hands-on problem-solving skills," he said. "We still faced some of the challenges that Hamilton faced. The light had to be designed and balanced so the mechanisms were hidden from view."

Collaboration and Innovation

Research engineer Mr. Andrew Kogios, who guided the students, praised their dedication and skill.

"From selecting materials and 3D printing, to troubleshooting electronics and satisfying requirements, working collaboratively with Yuji and Xinyu has been extremely rewarding," he said. "Experiences like these, supplementing their university studies, position them well for their future endeavors."

The completed mechanical volcano is now the highlight of The Grand Tour, an exhibition at the University of Melbourne's Baillieu Library that will be on display until June 28, 2026.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a meaningful educational and engineering achievement where students revived a 250-year-old mechanical volcano model using modern technology. This project blends historical art, science communication, and hands-on engineering skills, offering broad educational and cultural value. It highlights innovation, collaboration, and preservation of scientific heritage, which can inspire and uplift readers.
articles.personality_title: University students bring 250-year-old mechanical volcano to life
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 1775, Sir William Hamilton designed a mechanical model to imitate the eruption of Mount Vesuvius, combining art and early engineering. However, it was never built and remained only a sketch for 250 years.

**What happened** – Two students from the University of Melbourne, Xinyu Xu and Yuji Zeng, used modern tools like laser-cut wood, LED lights, and electronic controls to recreate Hamilton’s design. Their work brought the mechanical volcano to life for the first time, making it glow and move like a real eruption.

**Impact** – This project shows how old ideas can inspire new learning and creativity. It helped the students develop skills in programming, electronics, and mechanical design. It also brings history and science together, letting people see how art and technology combined centuries ago.

**What’s next step** – The mechanical volcano is now displayed at the University of Melbourne’s Baillieu Library until June 2026. The success of this project may encourage more students and researchers to explore historical inventions using modern technology.

**One-sentence takeaway** – University students revived a 250-year-old design to create a working mechanical volcano that connects history, science, and engineering in a new and exciting way.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des étudiants recréent un volcan mécanique vieux de 250 ans
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 1775, Sir William Hamilton a conçu un modèle mécanique pour imiter l’éruption du mont Vésuve, mêlant art et ingénierie ancienne. Cependant, ce projet n’a jamais été construit et est resté un simple dessin pendant 250 ans.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Deux étudiants de l’Université de Melbourne, Xinyu Xu et Yuji Zeng, ont utilisé des outils modernes comme le découpage laser, des lumières LED et des commandes électroniques pour recréer le modèle de Hamilton. Leur travail a donné vie au volcan mécanique pour la première fois, le faisant briller et bouger comme une vraie éruption.

**Impact** – Ce projet montre comment les idées anciennes peuvent inspirer l’apprentissage et la créativité actuels. Il a permis aux étudiants de développer des compétences en programmation, électronique et design mécanique. Il rassemble aussi histoire et science, montrant comment art et technologie pouvaient s’allier il y a des siècles.

**Prochaine étape** – Le volcan mécanique est maintenant exposé à la bibliothèque Baillieu de l’Université de Melbourne jusqu’en juin 2026. Ce succès pourrait encourager d’autres étudiants et chercheurs à explorer des inventions historiques avec la technologie moderne.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des étudiants ont recréé un modèle vieux de 250 ans pour fabriquer un volcan mécanique fonctionnel qui relie histoire, science et ingénierie de façon nouvelle et passionnante.
articles.personality_title_es: Estudiantes universitarios reviven un volcán mecánico de 250 años
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 1775, Sir William Hamilton diseñó un modelo mecánico para imitar la erupción del Monte Vesubio, combinando arte con ingeniería temprana. Sin embargo, nunca se construyó y quedó solo como un dibujo durante 250 años.

**Qué pasó** – Dos estudiantes de la Universidad de Melbourne, Xinyu Xu y Yuji Zeng, usaron herramientas modernas como corte láser, luces LED y controles electrónicos para reconstruir el diseño de Hamilton. Su trabajo dio vida al volcán mecánico por primera vez, haciendo que brillara y se moviera como una erupción real.

**Impacto** – Este proyecto muestra cómo las ideas antiguas pueden inspirar el aprendizaje y la creatividad actuales. Ayudó a los estudiantes a desarrollar habilidades en programación, electrónica y diseño mecánico. También une historia y ciencia, mostrando cómo arte y tecnología se combinaron hace siglos.

**Próximo paso** – El volcán mecánico está ahora en exhibición en la Biblioteca Baillieu de la Universidad de Melbourne hasta junio de 2026. El éxito de este proyecto podría animar a más estudiantes e investigadores a explorar inventos históricos con tecnología moderna.

**Frase clave** – Estudiantes universitarios revivieron un diseño de 250 años para crear un volcán mecánico funcional que conecta historia, ciencia e ingeniería de una manera nueva y emocionante.
